Award.AwardTitle: STEM-IQ: Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Inquiry- Enhancing Science Education in Southeast Alabama
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project tests the extent to which science fair participation addresses the opportunity gaps that limit STEM pipeline diversity, such as access to educational opportunities, exposure to career possibilities, quality of educational programs, and institutional and personal competitiveness. It focuses on advancing secondary school teachers' motivation and ability to lead their students in science fair projects, and develop a long-term appreciation for the effectiveness of inquiry-based learning. The five-year program targets rural, high-need schools, and economically disadvantaged students from underrepresented minority (URM) groups. The high quality, competitive, inquiry-based science fair projects lead students through a strong STEM pipeline leading to increased participation in higher education and potentially STEM careers.

Intellectual Merit
The project goals are to: (1) establish a network of STEM teachers and area administrators that pro-actively engage students in project-based learning and give them access to university resources and guidance to empower inquiry-based STEM learning; (2) increase the number of students from underrepresented groups in rural Alabama that participate in high-quality science fair projects; (3) develop a sustainable relationship between Auburn University and local public schools for continued growth beyond the scope of the project; and (4) increase positive student attitudes towards STEM through exposure to higher education, career options, and interactions with university research mentors. To accomplish these goals, the project leadership engages middle and high school teachers and administrators from vertically aligned schools (e.g., a middle school that feeds into a specific high school) in professional development workshops that focus on science and engineering fair project development and hosting local science fair competitions. Teachers and students develop high-quality science fair projects using university laboratories and faculty guidance. Trained teachers and administrators become agents of expanding the network and establishing a STEM culture in their schools.

Broader Impacts
The project leverages Auburn University?s College of Sciences and Mathematics Outreach Center activities to establish partnerships between Auburn University science and engineering faculty and high-need public schools in southeast Alabama. Over 720 students, 48 science teachers, and 12 administrators from 34 school districts are gaining access to Auburn University research facilities and faculty expertise in developing high-quality science fair projects. The program promotes a culture of project-based STEM learning and positive STEM identity among students who might not consider STEM higher education as an option. The model of university and local school system interaction to enhance URM interest and engagement in STEM higher education can be scaled and replicated nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education is a critical component of developing the future of a competitive nation.  While these are subjects taught in school, numerous studies have shown that hands-on forms of learning not only teach basic skills but promote independence and determination.  Our goal as educators is to not only teach but also inspire the next generation of leaders.

Science and Engineering Fairs increase students’ engagement and learning through direct experience with inquiry and design processes. These personal experiences with scientific inquiry and engineering design can spark lifelong passions for STEM topics. The goal of this project was to expand access to these important experiences to students who come from under-resourced schools in Alabama. We lowered the barriers for teachers in introducing fairs to their schools and ensured that all students had access to mentoring and materials needed for a successful fair experience.

The formal objective of the STEM-IQ project was to provide training, mentoring, and resources that would advance teachers’ motivation and ability to mentor students through participation in science fair. This was accomplished through four targeted goals: 1) to establish a network of STEM teachers and area administrators that advocate for students to engage in research experiences and give them the resources they need for implementation, 2) to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups in rural Alabama participating in high quality Science and Engineering project-based learning, 3) to develop a sustainable relationship between Auburn University and local public schools for continued growth beyond the scope of the project, and 4) to increase positive student attitudes towards STEM through interactions with university research mentors who serve as role models for the students.

Through STEM-IQ, the team successfully developed a learning community that linked university STEM faculty with K-12 students, teachers and administrators, facilitated through the Auburn University College of Sciences and Mathematics Outreach Center. Participation in the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair system provided a mechanism to enhance STEM education for students from Southeastern Alabama, which is a region heavily populated by underrepresented, underserved students in schools that struggle with imparting STEM knowledge and skills to their students.

We recruited teams of four to eight middle and high school teachers (46) from multiple schools (23) that serve a large percentage of under resourced and underrepresented populations in Alabama. Each year for three years, teachers received professional development (PD) training led by science and engineering faculty and STEM education specialists.  PD topics included constructing an appropriate hypothesis, project design and methodology, data analysis, graphical representation of data, helping students generate a solid testable question, hosting a local science fair, and identifying and training fair judges. Additionally, students and teachers visited the University campus for an annual event called Destination STEM, in which over 100 faculty and graduate students engaged participants in interactive experiences in science and engineering. Destination STEM provided an opportunity for students to explore science in a way they had never seen, prompting them to generate their own independent and unique project ideas.

Our findings showed that STEM-IQ (1)  prepared educators to teach through inquiry-based science, 2) promoted awareness of resources available through Auburn University, 3) provided teachers with tools that enabled students to produce high quality science fair projects, 4) developed teacher and student connections with Auburn faculty for both technical content and career guidance, 5) demonstrated the positive impact that science fair participation can have on college admission, scholarships, and preparedness for university courses, and 6) introduced students and teachers to diverse role models that empowered students to conceive of themselves as a scientific or technical professional.  Our findings suggest that students who completed projects and advanced to the regional fair had substantial positive outcomes in terms of attitude and transformative experiences. The strong representation of girls, African American, and Hispanic students indicates that the program was successful in increasing the positive impact that science and engineering fairs have on all students.  Finally, the positive relationships between teachers in the region and STEM faculty at the university through this project have resulted in numerous on-going collaborations that will impact student learning and opportunities in STEM for many years to come.
